title: How to Make a Folded Star Christmas Ornament

steps.headline: Obtain the needed materials.
steps.description:
3 fat quarters, or a quarter yard each of light weight fabrics in complimentary colors
Scissors and/or rotary cutter with cutting board
350 pins
A 3 inch (7.5 cm) Styrofoam ball
12 inches (30 cm) of inch (2.5 cm) wide lace (covers raw edges)
18 inches (45 cm) of 1/8th inch (3 mm) ribbon (hanging loop)
Approximate cost to make 4 ornaments is US/CAD$10, 6 pounds (UK)

steps.headline: Cut the fabric into 2 inch (5 cm) by 2 1/2 inch (6.5 cm) rectangles.
steps.description: For smaller or larger Styrofoam balls, you can measure the circumference of the ball and divide by 8, then add half an inch (or centimeter) for the height and width.

steps.headline: Place a square or rectangle of fabric on the ball and pin it in place by its corners.
Poke a pin through the center of the starting square and then into the ball.
steps.description: This will mark a starting point.

steps.headline: Poke a pin through the center of a piece of fabric.
Poke that same pin into the cloth covered area of the ball near the starter pin.
Fold the cloth down in half over itself.
Fold the corners down the center from the pinpoint to form a folded triangle.
Pin the bottom edge of the triangle with 4 pins.
steps.description: Use one for each end of the raw cloth edges.

steps.headline: Repeat this pin and fold action many more times, for a total of three rows per hemisphere as follows:
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg/460px-FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/d/d5/FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg/604px-FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":392,"bigWidth":"604","bigHeight":"515","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}4 points touching the pole. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/FFS-11a_531.jpg/460px-FFS-11a_531.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/1/18/FFS-11a_531.jpg/555px-FFS-11a_531.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":341,"bigWidth":"555","bigHeight":"412","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Row Two {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-11b_804.jpg/460px-FFS-11b_804.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-11b_804.jpg/526px-FFS-11b_804.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":480,"bigWidth":"526","bigHeight":"549","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg/460px-FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/4/47/FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg/584px-FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":320,"bigWidth":"584","bigHeight":"406","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}8 points in the next row, spacing the tips of the points approximately half an inch (1.27cm) below the pole, and lining the points up with the points above and the folded edges and lines with the row above. Check your measurement to see if three rows will reach the center meridian or not. Widen the distance between rows if necessary. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg/460px-FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg/603px-FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":396,"bigWidth":"603","bigHeight":"519","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}8 points in the third row should bring your raw edges to the equator. After three rows, if you have not reached the equator of the ball with the raw edges of your folded points, you will need to unpin and repin the rows with more or less spacing to compensate.

steps.headline: Find the "South Pole" of the ball.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg\/460px-FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg\/585px-FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":393,"bigWidth":"585","bigHeight":"500","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} Pin a new square on the ball and mark the center point. Mark the center point of the "South Pole".

steps.headline: Repeat the process of making rows of points from the "South Pole".
The ball should be totally covered by now, with a row of raw edges.
steps.description: The poles will appear as a "country star".

steps.headline: Pin and/or glue the ribbon or lace around the equator to cover up the raw edges.
Pin and/or glue a loop of ribbon to allow you to attach the ornament to your Christmas tree.
Graciously accept your friends' compliments and show them how you did it!

tyn: 3 fat quarters, or a quarter yard each of light weight fabrics in complimentary colors
Scissors and/or rotary cutter with cutting board
12 inches (30 cm) of inch (2.5 cm) wide lace (covers raw edges)
18 inches (45 cm) of 1/8th inch (3 mm) ribbon (hanging loop)
Approximate cost to make 4 ornaments is US/AUD/CAD$10, 6 pounds (UK)
text:
Obtain the needed materials. 3 fat quarters, or a quarter yard each of light weight fabrics in complimentary colors Scissors and/or rotary cutter with cutting board 350 pins A 3 inch (7.5 cm) Styrofoam ball 12 inches (30 cm) of inch (2.5 cm) wide lace (covers raw edges) 18 inches (45 cm) of 1/8th inch (3 mm) ribbon (hanging loop) Approximate cost to make 4 ornaments is US/CAD$10, 6 pounds (UK) Cut the fabric into 2 inch (5 cm) by 2 1/2 inch (6.5 cm) rectangles. For smaller or larger Styrofoam balls, you can measure the circumference of the ball and divide by 8, then add half an inch (or centimeter) for the height and width. Place a square or rectangle of fabric on the ball and pin it in place by its corners. Poke a pin through the center of the starting square and then into the ball. This will mark a starting point. Poke a pin through the center of a piece of fabric. Poke that same pin into the cloth covered area of the ball near the starter pin. Fold the cloth down in half over itself. Fold the corners down the center from the pinpoint to form a folded triangle. Pin the bottom edge of the triangle with 4 pins. Use one for each end of the raw cloth edges. Repeat this pin and fold action many more times, for a total of three rows per hemisphere as follows: {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg/460px-FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/d/d5/FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg/604px-FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":392,"bigWidth":"604","bigHeight":"515","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}4 points touching the pole. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/FFS-11a_531.jpg/460px-FFS-11a_531.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/1/18/FFS-11a_531.jpg/555px-FFS-11a_531.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":341,"bigWidth":"555","bigHeight":"412","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Row Two {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-11b_804.jpg/460px-FFS-11b_804.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-11b_804.jpg/526px-FFS-11b_804.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":480,"bigWidth":"526","bigHeight":"549","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg/460px-FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/4/47/FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg/584px-FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":320,"bigWidth":"584","bigHeight":"406","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}8 points in the next row, spacing the tips of the points approximately half an inch (1.27cm) below the pole, and lining the points up with the points above and the folded edges and lines with the row above. Check your measurement to see if three rows will reach the center meridian or not. Widen the distance between rows if necessary. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg/460px-FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/cb/FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg/603px-FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":396,"bigWidth":"603","bigHeight":"519","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}8 points in the third row should bring your raw edges to the equator. After three rows, if you have not reached the equator of the ball with the raw edges of your folded points, you will need to unpin and repin the rows with more or less spacing to compensate. Find the "South Pole" of the ball. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg/460px-FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/e/ec/FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg/585px-FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":393,"bigWidth":"585","bigHeight":"500","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Pin a new square on the ball and mark the center point. Mark the center point of the "South Pole". Repeat the process of making rows of points from the "South Pole". The ball should be totally covered by now, with a row of raw edges. The poles will appear as a "country star". Pin and/or glue the ribbon or lace around the equator to cover up the raw edges. Pin and/or glue a loop of ribbon to allow you to attach the ornament to your Christmas tree. Graciously accept your friends' compliments and show them how you did it!
sentences: Obtain the needed materials.

3 fat quarters, or a quarter yard each of light weight fabrics in complimentary colors
Scissors and/or rotary cutter with cutting board
350 pins
A 3 inch (7.5 cm) Styrofoam ball
12 inches (30 cm) of inch (2.5 cm) wide lace (covers raw edges)
18 inches (45 cm) of 1/8th inch (3 mm) ribbon (hanging loop)
Approximate cost to make 4 ornaments is US/CAD$10, 6 pounds (UK) Cut the fabric into 2 inch (5 cm) by 2 1/2 inch (6.5 cm) rectangles.
For smaller or larger Styrofoam balls, you can measure the circumference of the ball and divide by 8, then add half an inch (or centimeter) for the height and width.
Place a square or rectangle of fabric on the ball and pin it in place by its corners.
Poke a pin through the center of the starting square and then into the ball.
This will mark a starting point.
Poke a pin through the center of a piece of fabric.
Poke that same pin into the cloth covered area of the ball near the starter pin.
Fold the cloth down in half over itself.
Fold the corners down the center from the pinpoint to form a folded triangle.
Pin the bottom edge of the triangle with 4 pins.
Use one for each end of the raw cloth edges.

Repeat this pin and fold action many more times, for a total of three rows per hemisphere as follows: {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d5\/FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg\/460px-FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/d\/d5\/FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg\/604px-FFS-9_row_1_complete_49.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":392,"bigWidth":"604","bigHeight":"515","licensing":"

"} {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg/460px-FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/4/47/FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg/584px-FFS-11c_row_2_complete_624.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":320,"bigWidth":"584","bigHeight":"406","licensing":"

"}8 points in the next row, spacing the tips of the points approximately half an inch (1.27cm) below the pole, and lining the points up with the points above and the folded edges and lines with the row above.
Check your measurement to see if three rows will reach the center meridian or not.
Widen the distance between rows if necessary.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cb\/FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg\/460px-FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/c\/cb\/FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg\/603px-FFS-13-_row_3_complete_548.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":396,"bigWidth":"603","bigHeight":"519","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"}8 points in the third row should bring your raw edges to the equator.
After three rows, if you have not reached the equator of the ball with the raw edges of your folded points, you will need to unpin and repin the rows with more or less spacing to compensate.
Find the "South Pole" of the ball.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg\/460px-FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/e\/ec\/FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg\/585px-FFS-15_center_back_501.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":393,"bigWidth":"585","bigHeight":"500","licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} Pin a new square on the ball and mark the center point.
Mark the center point of the "South Pole".
Repeat the process of making rows of points from the "South Pole".
The ball should be totally covered by now, with a row of raw edges.
The poles will appear as a "country star".
Pin and/or glue the ribbon or lace around the equator to cover up the raw edges.
Pin and/or glue a loop of ribbon to allow you to attach the ornament to your Christmas tree.
Graciously accept your friends' compliments and show them how you did it!
